review_title: Ayn Rand - Eat your heart out
pros: Within my first three years I've been promoted twice, +50% hourly wage, travel weekly halfway across the US delivering great solutions in a niche industry, potential job security for decades, competitive salary and great benefits. I've worked in Oil & Gas, Aerospace & Defense, I now have a rolodex of engineers and developers from this job alone.
cons:
I got lucky, almost none of my coworkers hired alongside me are even still working here, and those that are aren't doing what they want. And that's not meant as a brag, there's no special sauce that kept me afloat in chargeability, I was simply selected for some internal job and bounced up from there. Take the "Pro" section as the potential here, not the standard.

Accenture demands your networking skills, your weekend hours, and part of your sanity. Your hours will be spent putting out manager's fires, you will hear "well, it has to be done by Monday" Friday at 4PM a lot. Your resume will sparkle but it will bleed you dry. Use it for networking and hope you find a nice project.

review_title: Projects are good, Company is not
pros: Smart co-workers, interesting projects, some nice benefits
cons:
Impossible to progress in the company due to excessive levels of cronyism. Employees are seen as disposable resources. You may work weekends, bank holidays, through sickness and long hours without recognition. Due to global nature and small size of local office, you may also be taking calls regularly between 12am-6am. Also due to clients based across the GCC - working 6 days a week is common. There is no focus on career progression or development of talent. Promotion budgets are constantly "low".
There is often no help or support on projects - the culture promotes existing team members taking on more at the detriment to the project and others to get themselves ahead. Extremely toxic workplace. Without being internally networked it is possible to be found excluded from new projects, certain office calls or distribution lists.

cons: Time based appraisal and not performance based

review_title: Fast paced, high stress, low pay, no work life balance
pros:
- Lots of opportunities to learn new things.

- No routine at all.

- Fast paced projects (for the ones who enjoy things moving super fast).

- Paternity Leave benefit (3 months).

- Very comprehensive Intranet Platform.

- Rich list of online courses in many areas, but you'll only have time for those in your rare and spare personal time...

- Lots of travel (again...if you like that and/or have no family to come back to). Pre Covid, of course.

- Lots of social activities (coffees, dinners, etc).

- Good place to work about Project Management.

- Possibility to relocate to other offices in other countries.

- Diverse workforce, with most people from international backgrounds.
cons:
- Most projects are too fast paced with high levels of toxicity and stress.

- Practically no work life balance, as the company implicitly encourages a culture of working overtime. 10-12 hrs/day is the norm during weekdays...and weekend work is very common as well. Forget about 9am-5pm work!

- High level of competition between employees, as you're ranked and compared to your peers during performance review time.

- Most projects have high levels of toxic people (from clients as well).

- Too many status meetings. It's not rare to have 3 a day (morning, afternoon, evening). On top of that, dozens of other meetings, only leaving the evening or weekend hours to actually do some work.

- Below the market salaries (at least up to Senior Manager level).

- Control freak micro management culture.

- Pressure to go into managerial roles. There's no technical career path.

- Too much travel (pre Covid, of course).

review_title: Too big for its own leadership to properly manage
job_title: Strategy Manager in New York, NY
pros:
-Opportunity to work in many industries
-Smart colleagues with experience in many places
-Access to extensive content databases
cons:
-Discrimination is an ongoing problem. Document, document, document--from the very first instance. Save your chats and emails. It probably won't happen to you, but if it does, expect to be let go under pretenses.
-Timecard manipulation is rampant--you are expected to violate company policy and underreport your project hours so the project looks more profitable for the managing director's record, damaging your own numbers in the process. If you don't, you aren't a "team player."
-Lack of consistency across a huge organization--they grew too fast and company culture, standard practices, nothing is consistent from practice to practice, manager to manager.
-What little training there is has nothing to do with the actual job
-Expect to be doing very little to no actual strategy work.
-Morale is poor--most seem to be there for a paycheck, nothing more, despite the smile they put on.
-Work Life balance. Expect to live out of a hotel room.
-The two strongest skills you can have are knowing PowerPoint shortcuts and brownnosing. Actual business knowledge, training, and judgment are nice-to-haves at best.
-If you have an MBA and actually want to use it, go anywhere else.

review_title: Caring, comfortable work environment, but slow growth
pros: The company really cares about you and your well being. The environment is stress free relative to other MNCs. Since the company is globally successfull, job security is good and you can focus more on delivering your goals. Great work-life balance.
cons: Growth is slow. The only way to get a substantial raise or promotion is to present an offer from another company. Sometimes, the promotions are based on seniority, which is a bad idea. Besides, the company suffers from whats called "MBAization" where fluffy talk and flashy jargon ridden presentations are encouraged.

pros:
Lot of chance to skill development but manage time is very difficult.
Due to high work pressure not easy to balance work life with personal life.
Provide very good compensation for skilled, hard working employees; OT, Comp-off, pay on holiday work, meal coupon including with CTC.
Company work culture is good ( depends on project). Accenture have strong HR policy listen to employee issues, connecting one on one as per request, even take action if required.
Job security is good; if project ramp down accommodate into different deals.
Growth depends on your performance; for me I get good increment after completion of 1 year with hard work in remote KT, project improvement, SOP creation, cross training, multiple Adhoc works.
Opportunities came if the employee is releasable resource else stick with same project.
Due to good behavior of Management, team members I feel good in Accenture comparison to my ex-companies.
Overall I can say if employee work well then they will be receive good benefits.
cons: Never say no to clients Adhoc request. Even if it not in the scope of any employee still need to deliver within very short time, extend working hours. But Accenture provide OT for that, sometimes it is hectic for employee perspective.

review_title: Great place to work if you know what you want
pros:
Supporting culture and respectful of boundaries if you strictly enforce them
Lots of opportunities available in any space one is interested in
Great growth trajectories and space to grow. If you're not growing, it's because you're in the wrong team. 
Committed to being better every day
cons:
Just like at any consulting firm, the more you give, the more they take and it can wear on you quickly. Mental health is not always a priority and culture tends to lead towards a "suck it up and do it" mentality. 
If you don't have clarity about what you want it is very easy for others to steer your career and lose control of what you actually want to do. This is a self-led company.
Huge firm, things are slow so one has to be patient
Pay could be better

pros: Potential to work with interesting clients
cons: Accenture's culture allows managing directors to keep their jobs by "stealing credit" for other people's work.  l'll explain.  If you are in a practice that has too many people and not enough work, some people will be laid off.  Let's suppose that you've created an opportunity with a new client.  A managing director that needs an engagement to keep occupied will take over the client and purposely abuse you so that you'll quit.  This clears the way for the managing director to replace you with a friend.  This is so common that I witnessed a managing director joke about how another managing director was "very good" at "stealing credit" for other people's work at a business dinner.

review_title: Benefits don't measure up, not remote-friendly, lousy equipment, cheap overall
pros:
Looks good on your resume.

Diversity is real here, that is a big plus.

Company provided phone.

Great networking
cons:
Insurance is expensive, high copays, ok deductibles, but very small network. All your doctors will be out of network.

During the pandemic they've been hiring people with the promise of having changed their tune on travel, but in reality, everybody is dying to travel and they will push you to travel as soon as you join a new assignment, and if you decline to travel, they'll find a way to get back at you for not doing so. They made vaccines a requisite for employment, but their pushing you to travel in spite of how contagious Omicron seems to be is counterintuitive.

Unless you get a technical job, you'll get the smallest, least powerful computer to basically just check email, and you get no budget to buy equipment to work from home.

Be aware that if you get a sign-in bonus you will have to pay it back if you quit before a year.

Most internal opportunities are staff-augmentation, narrow jobs, and the internal recruiters are eager to get you so they can fill their quotas.

As you'd expect, very cut-throat culture, they'll throw you under the bus at the first opportunity.

Not recommended if this is your first Consulting opportunity. Look elsewhere.
